title: Classic Olympic Moments
description: How well do you know these legendary Olympic moments?

questions.question: Which American track star won four gold medals at the 1936 Berlin Olympics, embarrassing Adolf Hitler's claims of Aryan supremacy?
questions.explanation: Jesse Owens won gold in the 100m, 200m, long jump, and 4x100m relay at the 1936 Berlin Olympics. His victories are considered one of the greatest repudiations of Nazi racial ideology.

questions.question: At which Olympics did the U.S. men's hockey team achieve the 'Miracle on Ice' by defeating the Soviet Union?
questions.explanation: The 1980 'Miracle on Ice' saw a team of young American college players defeat the heavily favored Soviet team 4-3 at the Lake Placid Winter Olympics. Al Michaels' call 'Do you believe in miracles? Yes!' became iconic.

questions.question: Which gymnast scored the first perfect 10 in Olympic history at the 1976 Montreal Games?
questions.explanation: Nadia Comaneci of Romania scored seven perfect 10s at the 1976 Montreal Olympics at just 14 years old. The scoreboard wasn't even designed to display a 10.00, showing 1.00 instead.

questions.question: What controversial event occurred during the 1972 Munich Olympics men's basketball final between the USA and Soviet Union?
options: A player was ejected for fighting
The clock was reset three times in the final seconds
The game went to five overtimes
Both teams boycotted the medal ceremony
questions.explanation: In one of the most controversial moments in Olympic history, officials put three seconds back on the clock multiple times, ultimately allowing the Soviet Union to score the winning basket. The U.S. team refused to accept their silver medals.

questions.question: Which boxer lit the Olympic cauldron at the 1996 Atlanta Games despite trembling from Parkinson's disease?
questions.explanation: Muhammad Ali's lighting of the Olympic cauldron at the 1996 Atlanta Games was one of the most emotional moments in Olympic history. Despite his trembling hands from Parkinson's, he held the torch steady to light the flame.

questions.question: At the 1968 Mexico City Olympics, what did Tommie Smith and John Carlos do on the medal podium that became an iconic symbol of protest?
options: Turned their backs to the flag
questions.explanation: Tommie Smith (gold) and John Carlos (bronze) raised black-gloved fists during the national anthem in a Black Power salute. The image became one of the most powerful political statements in sports history.

questions.question: Which American decathlete, who won gold at the 1976 Montreal Olympics, was declared 'the world's greatest athlete'?
questions.explanation: Bruce Jenner won the decathlon gold medal at the 1976 Montreal Olympics with a world-record score of 8,618 points. Jenner became an American cultural icon and appeared on the Wheaties box.

questions.question: What happened to American sprinter Mary Decker during the women's 3000m final at the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics?
options: She collided with Zola Budd and fell
She was tripped by a lane judge
questions.explanation: In one of the most heartbreaking Olympic moments, Mary Decker collided with barefoot South African-born runner Zola Budd during the 3000m final and fell to the track, ending her Olympic dream. The incident became a defining moment of the 1984 Games.

questions.question: Which swimmer won seven gold medals at the 1972 Munich Olympics, setting a record that stood for 36 years?
questions.explanation: Mark Spitz won seven gold medals at the 1972 Munich Olympics, setting world records in each event. His record stood until Michael Phelps won eight golds at the 2008 Beijing Olympics.

questions.question: At which Olympics did American Bob Beamon shatter the long jump world record by nearly two feet?
questions.explanation: Bob Beamon jumped 29 feet 2.5 inches at the 1968 Mexico City Olympics, beating the existing world record by 21.75 inches. The record stood for 23 years and is considered one of the greatest athletic achievements ever.

questions.question: Which country boycotted the 1980 Moscow Olympics, leading many Western nations to follow?
questions.explanation: The United States led a boycott of the 1980 Moscow Olympics in protest of the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan. About 65 countries joined the boycott, and the Soviet Union retaliated by boycotting the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics.

questions.question: Which American gymnast stuck a near-perfect vault landing on an injured ankle to clinch team gold at the 1996 Atlanta Olympics?
questions.explanation: Kerri Strug landed her second vault on a badly sprained ankle, scoring 9.712 to secure the first-ever team gold for the U.S. women's gymnastics team. Coach Bela Karolyi carrying her to the podium became an iconic image.

questions.question: At the 1960 Rome Olympics, which 18-year-old American boxer won the light heavyweight gold medal and later became one of the most famous athletes in history?
questions.explanation: Cassius Clay, who later changed his name to Muhammad Ali, won the light heavyweight gold medal at the 1960 Rome Olympics at age 18. It launched the career of arguably the greatest boxer who ever lived.

questions.question: Which runner, despite torn ligaments, was helped across the finish line by his father at the 1992 Barcelona Olympics?
questions.explanation: British sprinter Derek Redmond tore his hamstring during the 400m semi-final. His father, Jim, ran onto the track and helped him finish the race. The moment became one of the most touching in Olympic history.

questions.question: Which figure skater won Olympic gold in 1948 and 1952 and later starred in her own Hollywood ice shows?
questions.explanation: Sonja Henie of Norway actually won three consecutive Olympic golds in 1928, 1932, and 1936 before becoming a Hollywood star. Dick Button was the American who won men's figure skating gold in both 1948 and 1952.
